text.div:
Generated Narrative: CodeSystem space-cardiovascular-effects-cs

This case-sensitive code system https://mitre.org/fhir/space-health/CodeSystem/space-cardiovascular-effects-cs defines the following codes:

CodeDisplayDefinition
post-flight-orthostatic-intolerance Post-flight Orthostatic IntoleranceInability to maintain normal blood pressure when standing after return from spaceflight
cardiac-atrophy Cardiac AtrophyReduction in heart mass resulting from extended exposure to microgravity
vascular-remodeling Vascular RemodelingChanges in blood vessel structure and function as a result of spaceflight
baroreceptor-dysfunction Baroreceptor DysfunctionAltered function of baroreceptors responsible for regulating blood pressure during and after spaceflight
altered-cardiac-output Altered Cardiac OutputChanges in the volume of blood pumped by the heart during spaceflight
microgravity-induced-cardiac-arrhythmias Microgravity-Induced Cardiac ArrhythmiasAbnormal heart rhythms associated with adaptation to microgravity
venous-compliance-changes Venous Compliance ChangesAlterations in the capacity of veins to distend and store blood during spaceflight
cardiovascular-deconditioning Cardiovascular DeconditioningOverall decrease in cardiovascular function resulting from spaceflight

name: SpaceCardiovascularEffectsCodeSystem
title: Space Cardiovascular Effects
description: CodeSystem for space cardiovascular effects not found in SNOMED CT

concept.definition: Inability to maintain normal blood pressure when standing after return from spaceflight
Reduction in heart mass resulting from extended exposure to microgravity
Changes in blood vessel structure and function as a result of spaceflight
Altered function of baroreceptors responsible for regulating blood pressure during and after spaceflight
Changes in the volume of blood pumped by the heart during spaceflight
Abnormal heart rhythms associated with adaptation to microgravity
Alterations in the capacity of veins to distend and store blood during spaceflight
Overall decrease in cardiovascular function resulting from spaceflight
